title: Create /work command to orchestrate prep→cook→serve→tidy sequence
description:
Create a /work command for line-cook that orchestrates the full workflow loop:

1. /prep - sync state, load context, show available work
2. /cook - select and execute a task with guardrails
3. /serve - review completed work
4. /tidy - commit and push

The command should run each step in sequence, passing context between them. Provides a single entry point for a complete work cycle.

title: Create plugin from repo and install locally
Review meta-opencode for best practices on skills, commands, and plugins
description:
Review ~/code/meta-opencode to understand best practices for creating:
- Skills
- Commands  
- Plugins

Use findings to inform the opencode port of line-cook commands.

comments.author: Sam Biggins
comments.text:
Key findings from meta-opencode review:

## Commands (OpenCode)
- Location: .opencode/command/<name>.md or plugin/commands/<name>.md
- Frontmatter: description, agent, model, subtask
- Template variables: $ARGUMENTS, $1, $2, etc.
- Shell output: !`command`
- File references: @path/to/file

## Skills (OpenCode)
- Location: .opencode/skills/<name>/SKILL.md
- Frontmatter: name (kebab-case), description, license, compatibility, metadata
- Progressive disclosure: lazy-loadable subdirectories
- Must be SKILL.md (uppercase)

## Plugin Manifest (OpenCode)
- Uses package.json with 'opencode' section
- Lists skills[] and commands[] arrays
- Can be distributed as npm package (.tgz)

## Key Differences from Claude Code
- Commands in .opencode/command/ vs .claude/commands/
- Skills in .opencode/skills/ vs .claude/skills/
- Plugin manifest in package.json vs plugin.json
- Template syntax: $1/$2 vs $ARGUMENTS only in Claude

title: Add Mermaid diagram for workflow visualization

- Render nicely on GitHub

Gas Town uses Mermaid diagrams effectively to visualize system topology and workflows. The cyclical nature of Line Cook's workflow (and the fact that /work runs all four) would benefit from visual representation.

Consider showing:
- The four stages in sequence
- What each stage does (sync, execute, review, commit)
- The loop back from tidy to prep for next cycle
- Where human checkpoints occur

title: Reimagine line-cook as Go CLI tool
description:
Transform line-cook from a collection of Python hooks and markdown commands into a unified Go CLI tool (like beads uses 'bd'). The CLI would be the foundation that integrates with Claude Code hooks, git hooks, and plugins.

## Vision
- Single 'lc' or 'line' CLI binary
- Cross-platform (Windows, Linux, macOS) without Python dependency
- Hooks call the CLI instead of Python scripts
- Slash commands invoke CLI subcommands
- Git hooks integration for workflow automation

## Benefits
- No Python runtime dependency
- Faster execution (compiled binary)
- Single source of truth for all operations
- Easier distribution and installation
- Consistent behavior across platforms

title: OpenCode plugin requires permission prompts to read plugin files
description:
When using line-cook commands in OpenCode, the system prompts for permission to read plugin files from ~/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/line-cook-marketplace/line/. This breaks the workflow experience.

Files affected:
- ~/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/line-cook-marketplace/line/commands/*.md
- ~/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/line-cook-marketplace/line/.claude-plugin/plugin.json

Expected: Plugin files should be readable without permission prompts
Actual: Each command file requires explicit Read permission approval

This may be related to:
- Plugin installation method (marketplace vs direct)
- File permissions on the installed plugin directory
- OpenCode's permission model for plugin directories

title: Evaluate sections for progressive disclosure to linked docs
description:
Some README sections may be better as separate linked documents. This keeps the main README scannable while preserving depth for those who need it.

Candidates to evaluate:
- **Influences section** - Could become INFLUENCES.md or PHILOSOPHY.md, with README having a brief mention and link
- **Installation details** - Online/offline options for two platforms is verbose. Could link to INSTALL.md
- **Hooks section** - Already links to HOOKS.md, but maybe the README mention should be even shorter
- **Project Structure** - Detailed tree could move to CONTRIBUTING.md or DEVELOPMENT.md

Principles:
- README should be <500 lines ideally
- First-time readers need: what is it, quick start, install, basic usage
- Contributors/power users can follow links for depth
- Don't fragment so much that context is lost

Review beads and Gas Town READMEs for how they handle this balance.

title: Add callout blocks for prerequisites, tips, warnings
description:
Gas Town uses visual callout blocks to create hierarchy:
- Prerequisites stand out
- Tips are visually distinct
- Warnings catch attention

GitHub Markdown supports these via blockquotes with emoji or via alert syntax:

> [!NOTE]
> Useful information

> [!TIP]  
> Helpful advice

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Key information

> [!WARNING]
> Urgent info

> [!CAUTION]
> Negative potential consequences

Line Cook should add callouts for:
- Prerequisites: 'beads is required—install it first'
- Tip: 'Run /line:work for the full cycle, or individual commands for more control'
- Important: 'Plan your work in beads BEFORE using Line Cook'
- Warning: Session close protocol (push before stop)

title: Research manual compaction/rewind/clear for workflow integration
description:
Explore if Claude Code and OpenCode expose manual controls for context management that Line Cook could integrate with.

Areas to research:

**Claude Code:**
- Manual compaction trigger (is there a command or API?)
- Rewind functionality (can you roll back to earlier context state?)
- Clear/new session (how to programmatically start fresh?)
- PreCompact hook - we know this exists, but can we TRIGGER compaction?

**OpenCode:**
- Equivalent context management features
- Any exposed commands or APIs

**Potential workflow integrations:**
- /line:checkpoint - Save context state before risky operations
- /line:fresh - Clear context and re-prime with current task only
- /line:compact - Trigger compaction with Line Cook context preserved
- Post-tidy auto-compact to start next cycle with clean context

**Questions to answer:**
1. What context management is exposed to users/plugins?
2. Can hooks interact with compaction (beyond just observing PreCompact)?
3. Is there a way to inject summary content during compaction?
4. How does Gas Town handle long-running sessions?

This is exploratory research - may not result in features if the platforms don't expose these controls.
